I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) supports the Government of the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) to (i) improve investment policy; and (ii) promote business 
innovation, workplace skills development, and employment facilitation. The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) conducted a fact-finding mission on 16–17 February 2017, and obtained government 
concurrence on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants.1 Previous consultations on the TA were 
held in September and November 2016. The September 2016 mission included a presentation 
on ADB’s workplace skills and employment facilitation projects implemented in the Philippines. 
The TA is included in the Lao PDR country operations business plan, 2017–2019.2 The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Development challenges. The Lao PDR experienced robust economic growth during 
2011–2015, averaging 7.6% of gross domestic product annually. The resource sector in the Lao 
PDR is a key growth driver, with large-scale foreign direct investments in hydropower and mining 
accounting for one-third of the country’s gross domestic product. However, the mining sector 
accounts for only 0.5% of total employment.4 With half of the population under the age of 24 and 
almost 100,000 new job seekers entering the labor market each year, there is strong pressure to 
create  wage  employment  in  the  non-resource sectors, such  as  tourism,  agribusiness,  and 
business services. The government recognizes that the target to implement the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Economic Community consolidated strategic action plan by 
2025 is a potential catalyst for growth in the non-resource sectors and domestic job creation. Also, 
the government recognizes that, to benefit from trade in goods and services, it needs to create a 
policy environment to attract investments, boost enterprise productivity, and facilitate youth 
employment. 
 
3.  Binding constraints. The ability of enterprises to raise productivity is constrained by an 
inadequate investment policy framework and lack of market-based incentives for enterprises to 
innovate and invest in workplace skills training. Existing labor market programs are not equipped 
to respond to employer hiring needs, resulting in difficulties for young people to find jobs after 
graduating from high school. For example, the 2009 Investment Promotion Law5 established an 
incentive  framework  that  has  had  the  unintended  consequence  of  attracting  short-term 
investments  based  on  generous  income  tax  incentives  rather  than  attracting  longer-term 
employment-generating investments in the non-resource sector. A complex investment licensing 
and regulatory environment has also suppressed investments in the non-resource sector. At the 
end of 2016, the government submitted amendments to the Investment Promotion Law to rectify 
deficiencies in incentives and the licensing regime; these amendments, once approved, will be 
implemented by the government in 2017–2018. One of the key amendments will establish a one-
stop investment licensing service center to make it easier for foreign and domestic investors to 
establish operations in the Lao PDR.

4.  Domestic enterprises are characterized by low productivity levels as a result of not 
investing adequately in basic innovative activities and workplace skills.6 For example, a 2014 
enterprise survey reported that only 8% of respondents invested in short-term skills training.7 
Global good practices show that publicly funded schemes to promote enterprise innovation and 
investments  in  workplace  skills  can  be  catalysts  for  improving  enterprise  productivity  and 
adaptability to changes in markets. In the Lao PDR, there are no public funding schemes 
incentivizing enterprises to innovate and invest in workplace skills. 
 
5.  Active labor market programs are critical to help young people prepare for the labor market 
and help employers find the right employees. Public employment service centers (PESCs) are 
platforms for implementing active labor market programs and facilitating job placements. In the 
Lao PDR, there are 10 PESCs located in the country’s main urban centers that provide only basic, 
low-level employment facilitation services such as posting job vacancies and employer referrals. 
ADB is providing TA to the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare to establish labor market 
information systems and build capacity of the 10 PESCs.8 International best practice shows that 
it is critical for the PESCs to also implement youth employment programs that: (i) are employer 
demand-driven; and (ii) provide an integrated set of services to youth such as career guidance, 
life  skills  training,  industry-specific  technical  training,  and  placements  or  internships  with 
employers.9 
 
6.  Government’s strategy. The government’s approach to addressing these constraints is 
articulated in the government’s Eighth Five-Year National Socio-Economic Development Plan, 
2016–2020,10 and can be categorized into three policy areas: (i) creating an enabling business 
environment;  (ii)  promoting  investments  in  business  innovations  and  workforce  skills 
development; and (iii) implementing employment facilitation programs. Under the first area, the 
government has: (i) implemented a competition policy since 2015; (ii) enacted legislation that 
mandates regulatory impact assessments (RIAs) across government; (iii) implemented a modern 
enterprise registration system; and (iv) implemented a credit information bureau and a secured 
transaction registry. These interventions have improved the Lao PDR’s business climate. The 
World Bank’s 2017 Doing Business report shows the Lao PDR has improved significantly in the 
areas of obtaining a business permit (ranked 139th in 2017 from 150th in 2010) and getting credit 
(ranked 75th in 2017 from 89th in 2010). With these foundational reforms in place, the government 
is looking at ways to strengthen its innovation policy and intellectual property rights protection, 
and develop an incentives framework to encourage business innovations and short-term skills 
training. Under employment facilitation, the government’s strategy is to improve the capacity of 
PESCs, establish a labor market information system, and design and implement active labor 
market programs to support youth as they prepare to enter the labor market. 
 
7.  ADB experience. ADB has supported the government’s private sector development 
agenda including the development of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through loan 
programs, investment project loans, a series of TA grants, and knowledge products. The Private 
Sector and Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program loans, 2008–2013, 
supported the government’s  implementation  of foundational reforms for  SME  development,

for the benefit of SMEs.12 An ongoing capacity development TA loan and a TA grant have 
supported  the  government’s  RIA  implementation,13 enhanced  the  enterprise  registry,  and

learned from the TA activities will be used to formulate a sector development program loan in

8.  Risks. Identified risks include a change in government leadership resulting in shift in 
priorities, which may prevent the incorporation of recommendations in policy decisions. This will 
be mitigated through frequent engagement with government stakeholders to firmly integrate the 
TA outputs in the policy decision-making process across different ministries. Another identified 
risk is possible duplication among donors on topics related to the TA. To mitigate this risk, donor 
coordination efforts will continue during TA implementation. 
 
9.  Lessons applied and donor coordination. ADB’s experience provided the following four 
lessons, which were incorporated into the TA: 
(i)  There is a need to bring business innovation, workplace skills development, and 
employment facilitation under one policy framework to link businesses and the 
labor market; 
(ii)  Successful ADB programs, projects, and TA projects work with a small number of 
implementing agencies with established sector-based strategies and proven track 
records in reaching out to stakeholders for input and ownership; 
(iii)  Policy reforms and interventions need to be in sequence. ADB’s assistance, from 
2011, focused on an enabling business environment, while interventions are now 
needed to improve enterprise productivity so that they benefit from the Association 
of Southeast Asian Nations Economic Community; and 
(iv)  For ADB’s policy assistance to be sustainable, local economists and researchers 
should contribute their perspective and expertise on locally suitable policies and 
initiatives. Thus, the TA supports the development of a pool of local experts and 
researchers who can contribute to policy development.

III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact will be the achievement of inclusive economic growth and employment 
generation, in line with the Eighth Five-Year National Socio-Economic Development Plan, 2016–
2020.16 The outcome will be strengthened economic policy formulation and implementation 
processes. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA has four outputs (paras. 11–14). Indicators and performance targets in relation to 
the four outputs are in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  Output  1:  Investment  policy  framework  improved.  This  output  will  support  the 
enhancement of investment policy development and implementation of the amended Investment 
Promotion  Law  to  increase  economic  activity  in  non-resource  sectors  by:  (i)  conducting  a 
stocktaking of existing investment policies and incentives; (ii) identifying lessons learned and new 
global practices in promoting domestic and foreign investment applicable to the Lao PDR context; 
(iii) developing suggestions for policy incentives for promoting investments in priority sectors; and 
(iv) supporting the implementation of key provisions of the revised Investment Promotion Law 
such as the establishment of a one-stop business registration center. 
 
14.  Output 2: Innovation and workplace skills development policy framework improved. 
This output will support policy advisory and capacity development for improving enterprise 
innovation  and  workplace  skills.  Activities  will  include:  (i)  conducting  a  stocktaking  of  and 
identifying lessons learned from existing workplace skills policies; (ii) conducting a stocktaking of 
and identifying lessons learned from existing innovation policy, including intellectual property 
rights;  (iii)  identifying  global  best  practices  for  promoting  innovation  and  workplace  skills 
development applicable in the Lao PDR context; (iv) making recommendations on policies, 
programs, and public financing schemes for promoting innovative activities at the enterprise level; 
and (v) making recommendations on policies, programs, and public financing schemes for 
promoting employer-led skills development in the workplace in priority growth sectors. 
 
15.  Output 3: Employment facilitation programs developed. This output will facilitate labor 
market activation programs to help young people become job ready, find jobs, and address skills 
mismatches. It will focus on key groups of job seekers such as out-of-school youth, workers who 
require retraining, and other vulnerable labor groups. Activities will include: (i) conducting a 
stocktaking of and identifying lessons learned from existing employment policies and programs; 
(ii) carrying out a youth school-to-work transition survey and a skills and employment survey to 
provide input for a joint ADB–Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) 
publication on employment and skills mismatch;17 and (iii) making recommendations for pilot 
projects on labor market activation programs that provide integrated comprehensive employment 
services to youth. This output will draw on ADB’s experience in implementing labor market 
activation programs in the Philippines (footnote 15).

Development Plan, 2016–2020. Vientiane. 
17 This collaboration will be covered under a knowledge partnership agreement between ADB and OECD.

16.  Output 4: Linkages with centers of excellence established. With the aim of enhancing 
the pool of policy research expertise, this output will support policy research for priority topics 
identified by the government as well as capacity development of local think tanks. Two major 
activities will be undertaken as part of this output: (i) provision of research grants to Lao 
researchers in priority topics identified by government agencies; and (ii) capacity building for local 
think tanks through training on research methodology, data analysis, and software, as well as on-
the-job training with international research mentors. Partners under this activity include the 
National University of Laos, National Economic Research Institute, and the Development Policy 
Research Center of the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,050,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 6. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, remuneration, 
domestic transportation of counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The executing agency is the MPI. It will chair the TA steering committee, with implementing 
agencies and other relevant stakeholders as members. The committee will meet biannually to 
report on and discuss TA outputs. The implementing agencies are the Department of Investment 
Promotion of the MPI (output 1), the Ministry of Science and Technology (output 2), the Ministry 
of Labor and Social Welfare (outputs 2 and 3), and the Ministry of Finance (output 4).  
 
19.  The Ministry of Finance will establish and chair a research awards committee with 
participation from implementing agencies and ADB to identify research topics and select research 
grantees through a competitive process. Under output 4, 10 research grantees will be awarded 
research grants of up to a total amount of $35,000. Each researcher will be engaged as a resource 
person through ADB’s consultant management system. The guidelines for selecting grantees will 
be developed during the TA implementation stage. Individual consultants will be engaged to 
implement the TA activities. A national firm will be engaged for the employment survey listed in 
Output 3. Details of consultant recruitment are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time). Upon TA completion, all 
equipment purchased under the TA will be handed over to the executing agency in accordance 
with relevant ADB guidelines. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 36 months from May 2017 to April 2020 
following the signing  of  the TA  agreement  between  the government and  ADB.  Consultant 
deliverables are in the outline terms of reference for consultants in Appendix 3.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Economic Policy Support for 
Enhancing Productivity and Employment, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of five international consultants and three national consultants will be recruited by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through individual contract to implement activities under 
outputs 1–4. The five international consultants will be recruited for a total of 25 person-months, 
with expertise in investment policy (one expert for 10 person-months), innovation policy (one 
expert for 4 person-months), workplace skills (one expert for 4 person-months), labor market 
activation programs (one expert for 4 person-months), and statistics (one expert for 3 person-
months). 
 
2.  Three individual national consultants (12 person-months each: one finance officer, one 
administrator,  and  one  grants  coordinator)  will  be  responsible  for  supporting  the  technical 
assistance (TA) project management unit and the TA committees. Individual consultants will be 
engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time). A national firm will also be engaged through consultants’ qualifications 
selection for up to $40,000 to carry out a survey of 500 households to report on school-to-work 
transition of youth in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), which will also provide 
supporting data to the joint ADB-Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development 
(OECD) study on employment. The detailed terms of reference for consultants are in paras. 5–
20. 
 
3.  Consultants will be supervised by ADB’s project manager, and report to the project 
executing agency and implementing agencies. Consultants will be required to report findings 
through inception, interim, and final reports. 
 
A.  Investment Policy Expert and Team Leader (international, 10 person-months) 
4.  The expert will work closely with the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) to assess 
the current national investment policy framework, consult with relevant stakeholders, and make 
recommendations for reform based on best practices adapted to the Lao PDR context. 
 
5.  Specific  deliverables  include  an  inception  plan,  quarterly  progress  reports,  and  a 
recommendation paper for investment policy reform. The expert will perform the following: (i) 
review investment policies; (ii) synthesize good global practices on investment policy framework 
with a focus on taxation, fiscal and non-fiscal incentives, and investment regulatory approval 
processes; (iii) make suggestions for policy improvements; (iv) plan and design policy workshops 
or training as necessary; and (v) support the MPI’s implementation of the amended Investment 
Promotion Law covering the one-stop business registration center and other mandates. 
 
6.  The expert should have at least 10 years of professional experience in investment policy 
frameworks for both advanced and emerging economies, and should have at least a master’s 
degree in economics, finance, or an equivalent discipline. Familiarity with the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) investment framework, including the ASEAN Comprehensive 
Investment Agreement, would be an advantage. 
 
7.  The expert will report to the MPI and ADB’s project officer. Assignment will be in Vientiane 
on an intermittent basis over a 24-month period from mid-2017 to mid-2019. The expert will 
undertake  five  field  missions  to  Vientiane  to  provide  necessary  support  and  carry  out 
consultations with key stakeholders.

Appendix 3  11 
B.  Innovation Policy Expert (international, 4 person-months)  
 
8.  The expert will work closely with the Ministry of Science and Technology to assess the 
current national innovation policy framework, consult with relevant stakeholders, and make 
recommendations for reform based on best practices adapted to the Lao PDR context. 
 
9.  Specific  deliverables  include  an  inception  plan,  quarterly  progress  reports,  and  a 
recommendation paper for innovation policy reform. The expert will perform the following: (i) 
review existing business innovation policies, (ii) synthesize good global practices on promoting 
business innovation with a focus on adapting them to the Lao PDR context, and (iii) make 
suggestions for policy improvements and capacity-building initiatives. 
 
10.  The expert should have at least 10 years of professional experience in innovation policy 
frameworks for both advanced and emerging economies, and should have at least a master’s 
degree in business, science and technology, or an equivalent discipline. 
 
11.  The expert will report to the Ministry of Science and Technology and ADB’s project officer. 
Assignment will be in Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 4-month period from mid-2017 to 
mid-2018. The expert will undertake three field missions to Vientiane to provide necessary support 
and carry out consultations with key stakeholders. 
 
C.  Workplace Skills Expert (international, 4 person-months) 
 
12.  The expert will work closely with the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare (MLSW) to 
assess the current workplace skills policy framework, consult with relevant stakeholders, and 
make recommendations for reform based on best practices adapted to the Lao PDR context. 
 
13.  Specific  deliverables  include  an  inception  plan,  quarterly  progress  reports,  and  a 
recommendation paper for workplace skills development policy reform. The expert will perform 
the following: (i) review existing workplace skills programs, (ii) synthesize good global practices 
on enhancing workplace skills with a focus on adapting them to the Lao PDR context, and (iii) 
make suggestions for policy improvements and capacity-building initiatives.  
 
14.  The expert should have at least 10 years of professional experience in human resource 
development policy frameworks for both advanced and emerging economies, and should have at 
least a master’s degree in human resource development or an equivalent discipline. 
 
15.  The expert will report to the MLSW and ADB’s project officer. Assignment will be in 
Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 4-month period from mid-2017 to the end of 2017. The 
expert will undertake three field missions to Vientiane to provide necessary support and carry out 
consultations with key stakeholders. 
 
D.  Labor Market Activation Expert (international, 4 person-months)  
 
16.  The expert will work closely with the MLSW to assess the current labor market policy 
framework, consult with relevant stakeholders, and make recommendations for reform based on 
best practices adapted to the Lao PDR context. 
 
17.  Specific  deliverables  include  an  inception  plan,  quarterly  progress  reports,  and  a 
recommendation paper for labor market activation policy reform. The expert will perform the 
following:  (i)  review  existing  employment  facilitation  programs;  (ii)  synthesize  good  global

12  Appendix 3 
practices on enhancing employment facilitation with a focus on adapting them to the Lao PDR 
context; and (iii) design a full-cycle youth employment program responding to labor market needs 
and helping local youth to become job ready. Using the data collected from the employment 
survey, the expert will prepare a report on school-to-work transition in the Lao PDR. 
 
18.  The expert should have at least 10 years of professional experience in the design of labor 
market programs and policy frameworks for both advanced and emerging economies, and should 
have at least a bachelor’s degree in economics, finance, public policy management, or an 
equivalent discipline. 
 
19.  The expert will report to the MLSW and ADB’s project officer. Assignment will be in 
Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 4-month period from mid-2017 to mid-2018. The expert 
will undertake three field missions to Vientiane to provide necessary support and carry out 
consultations with key stakeholders. 
 
E.  Statistician (international, 3 person-months) 
 
20.  The statistician will work with the centers of excellence and the project team on research 
and provision of data analysis contributing toward the formulation of policy advice and a baseline 
assessment of project deliverables. The statistician will develop the survey instruments for the 
household employment survey, carry out and complete the statistical analysis for the employment 
facilitation (school-to-work transition) program, and provide any other statistical support needed 
for the OECD employment study. 
  
21.  The statistician should have at least 10 years of professional experience in economic 
research for both advanced and emerging economies, and should have at least a master’s degree 
in economics, public policy management, or an equivalent discipline. 
 
22.  The statistician will report to the MPI and ADB’s project officer. Assignment will be in 
Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 3-month period from mid-2017 to mid-2019. The 
statistician will undertake two field missions to Vientiane to provide necessary support and carry 
out consultations with key stakeholders. 
 
F.  Finance Officer (national, 12 person-months) 
 
23.  The finance officer will work with the executing agency, implementing agencies, and 
ADB’s project team to administer and manage the project budget, including preparing financial 
reports every quarter. 
 
24.  Specific deliverables of the finance officer include quarterly budget reports, financial 
statements, and annual financial reports. The finance officer will perform the following: (i) make 
payments  for  expenditures  incurred  under  the  TA;  (ii)  maintain  TA  project  accounts;  and  
(iii) provide regular budget reports to the executing agency and ADB’s project officers. 
 
25.  The finance officer should have a degree in accounting or its equivalent, and have at least 
8 years of experience in project management or accounting in emerging economies. Prior 
experience with development partners would be an advantage. 
 
26.  The finance officer will report to the MPI and ADB’s project officer. Assignment will be in 
Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 12-month period from mid-2017 to the end of 2019.

Appendix 3  13 
G.  Project Manager (national, 12 person-months) 
 
27.  The project manager will be responsible for project management and administration, 
including coordination with the government both in Vientiane and in the provinces, as necessary. 
The project manager will support day-to-day communication with the government for project 
management  and  administration;  organize  training  activities  as  necessary;  and  facilitate 
coordination  with  other  stakeholders  such  as  the  private  sector,  academics,  and  public 
employment service centers. 
 
28.  Specific deliverables of the project manager include overall coordination of the project; 
administration  of  TA  activities;  and  regular  communication  between  the  executing  agency, 
implementing agencies, ADB, and consultants. The project manager will perform the following:  
(i)  TA  logistics  such  as  scheduling  of  meetings  and  coordinating  with  local  government 
counterparts; (ii) day-to-day office operations for the TA; and (iii) facilitating the progress of TA 
activity implementation. 
 
29.  The project manager should have a bachelor’s degree in economics or its equivalent, and 
have at least 8 years of experience in project management or public service in the Lao PDR. The 
administrative officer must have well-developed interactive and interpersonal skills and be task 
oriented. Extensive experience in facilitation assignments with government bodies, especially 
local government bodies, would be highly desirable. Prior experience with development partners 
would be an advantage. 
 
30.  The administrative officer will report to the MPI and ADB’s project officer. Assignment will 
be in Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 12-month period from mid-2017 to the end of 2019. 
 
H.  Research Grants Coordinator (national, 12 person-months) 
 
31.  The coordinator will work with ADB’s project team and coordinate with the centers of 
excellence to assess and administer research grants for output 4. 
 
32.  The coordinator should have at least 6 years of professional experience in economic 
research for both advanced and emerging economies, and should have at least a degree in 
economics, public policy management, or an equivalent discipline. 
 
33.  The coordinator will report to the research awards committee and ADB’s project officer. 
Assignment will be in Vientiane on an intermittent basis over a 12-month period from mid-2017 to 
mid-2019. 
 
I.  Policy Researchers (10 grantees will be awarded research grants of up to a total of 
$35,000)  
 
34.  The policy researchers will be selected based on the relevance of their research proposals 
consistent with the government’s priorities under output 4. The researchers will write and publish 
research papers supporting policy formulation and/or reform in areas related to outputs 1–3. 
 
35.  Each researcher should have at least 8 years of experience in economic research for both 
advanced and emerging economies, and should have at least a master’s degree in development 
economics, public policy management, or an equivalent discipline.

14  Appendix 3 
J.  Survey Firm (national, up to $40,000) 
 
36.  The  survey  firm  will  be  recruited  to  conduct  the  employment  survey  across  local 
households, listed in output 3. This survey will contribute data for: (i) a report on the Lao PDR 
youth school-to-work transition, drafted by ADB; (ii) the ADB–OECD skills and employment survey; 
and (iii) an assessment with recommendations on a comprehensive employment facilitation 
program that can be supported at the national level. The survey results will also support the ADB–
OECD employment study targeted for 2019. 
 
37.  The consultants of the survey firm should have bachelor’s degrees in statistics, economics, 
or an equivalent discipline, and have at least 6 years of research and field survey experience in 
developing markets, in particular in the ASEAN region. 
 
K.  ADB–Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  Employment 
Study (ADB’s contribution up to $70,000) 
 
38.  The knowledge partnership agreement with OECD is slated to be finalized in 2019. ADB 
and OECD will jointly carry out a study on workplace skills and employment, similar to the ADB–
OECD employment study conducted in 2016 in the Philippines.1 The study will map the demand 
of employers in the Lao PDR and match identified demands against existing skill sets of the local 
workforce. Through this exercise, the study will identify gaps in skill sets and other factors causing 
low employment rates. The study will build on the data collected by the national survey firm. OECD 
will conduct data collection and mapping, study visits, and research and local interviews, and will 
prepare the report and action plan as part of the study. 
                                                
1  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. 2016. OECD Employment and Skill Strategies in the 
Philippines. Paris.
